note.p: Lewis M. Hall was a law enforcement officer and public official in Mississippi during the Reconstruction official.

His year and location of birth are unclear, as Hall first appears in the public record in Mississippi in 1864, during federal occupation of Vicksburg. He apparently served as an agent of the Freedmen’s Bureau in that city, receiving property in the commission of the bureaur’s work. At the end of the Civil War, Hall advertised a merchant business, in which he imported northern goods for sale in Vicksburg. By the late 1860s, however, he had turned to public office, serving as Justice of the Peace and a notary public in Vicksburg.

In 1870, Hall received an appointment by Governor James L. Alcorn as chief detective in command of a state secret service unit. Hall led a group of seven detectives, two of whom were African American, given sweeping authority by the governor to investigate and arrest people suspected of committing violent crimes during a period of intense political and racial tensions. The unit lasted only one year before it lost funding and dissolved in the face of criticism by Alcorn’s political opponents. Hall continued to work in law enforcement, serving as sheriff of Warren County, as marshal in Vicksburg, and then as the city’s chief of police in the early 1870s. In early 1874, he was arrested for taking bribes to allow gambling establishments to remain in the community. Despite these charges, he was a Republican candidate for mayor of Vicksburg that same year, but died of illness on June 23, 1874.

(The Vicksburg Herald, Vicksburg, MS, January 9, 1866, and October 10, 1869; The Vicksburg Daily Times, Vicksburg, MS, January 13, 1872; The Vicksburg Herald, Vicksburg, MS, August 4, 1874; Warren County, Mississippi, Probate Court Docket, 1810-1940; William T. Blain, “Challenge to the Lawless: The Mississippi Secret Service, 1870-1871,” The Mississippi Quarterly, Vol. 31, No. 2 [Spring 1978], pp. 229-240; Records of the Field Offices for the State of Mississippi, Bureau of Refugeees, Freedmen, and Abandoned Lands, 1865-1872; The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, MS, June 25, 1874; Newton Weekly Ledger, Newton, MS, March 12, 1874; Lucas Somers, “Gov. Alcorn’s Secret Service Infiltrates the Ku Klux Klan – Part 1,” May 20, 2022, CWRGM Blog)

catDesc.term: Railroads and Railroad Companies--Baltimore and Ohio Railroad (Baltimore, Md.)

gloss.p: Headquartered in Baltimore, Maryland, the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad was a railroad company that operated from 1830 until 1987. The rail lines went west from the port of Baltimore, with stations at Sandy Hook, Maryland (1834), Cumberland (1842), Moundsville, Virginia (1852), Wheeling, Virginia (1853), and Parkersburg, Virginia (1857). The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad assisted the Union throughout the Civil War. (Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: Railroads and Railroad Companies--Mississippi and Tennessee Railroad (Memphis, Tenn.)

gloss.p: Running from Memphis, Tennessee to Grenada, Mississippi, the Mississippi and Tennessee Railroad was a railroad company incorporated on October 16, 1852 and operated until 1886, when Illinois Central Railroad purchased the company. (Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: Railroads and Railroad Companies--Mississippi Central Railroad Company (1852-1877)

gloss.p: Located in Holly Springs, Mississippi, the Mississippi Central Railroad Company was a railroad company operating from 1852 to 1877. The Mississippi Central Railroad Company was impacted by General Grant's Mississippi Central Railroad Campaign of November 1862, whereby the Union destroyed a large portion of the rail line, cutting off the Confederacy from supplies and causing a retreat, thwarting General Grant's overall goal of the campaign, which was to seize control of Vicksburg, Mississippi. (Wikipedia)

A military headquarters is the main center of control for a unit and typically revolves around that unit’s highest ranking officer. The term headquarters often refers to a physical location, however it is not always a permanent facility. A commanding officer can establish a headquarters anywhere that best allows oversight of the unit. Frequently during the Civil War military leaders relocated their headquarters each day as their armies moved. Union general John Pope famously declared that he would make his “headquarters in the saddle.” The comment was more symbolic than literal, but reflected how a headquarters centered on the commander's location and was subject to his discretion in how and where to conduct official duties. Pope’s critics replied that he was making his headquarters where his “hindquarters” should be, representing the more traditional view of a headquarters being a stationary command center strategically located for the effective management of a staff and army. (Cambridge Dictionary)

gloss.p: During the Civil War, Confederate military authorities used different levels of operational command to oversee their growing military forces and to respond to federal campaigns against the south. The military department proved to be one of the more effective levels of command for territorial areas. The department commanders reported directly to the Confederate War Department and Confederate president Jefferson Davis. Initially Confederate officials created military departments only for areas directly under federal attack. As the war developed, they created departments to cover the entire Confederacy. Confederate authorities restructured the departments as the war developed, and Union forces captured some parts of the Confederacy or military campaigns created new military needs in geographical areas. Some old departments were dissolved, or divided, and territories placed within new departments designed for contemporary needs.

The first department to include parts of Mississippi was the Department of Mississippi and East Louisiana, established on October 1, 1862. It existed until January 28, 1864, when Confederate authorities created the new department of Alabama and East Mississippi. That department lasted until August 15, 1864, and the creation of the Department of Alabama, Mississippi, and Eastern Louisiana, which lasted until May 1865 and the end of the war. (Americancivilwarhighcommand.com)

gloss.p: The office of Quartermaster General was primarily responsible for the acquisition, development, and dispersal of food and uniforms within the army. At the outbreak of the Civil War, Union and Confederate officials had to expand the Quartermaster capabilities and structure to support the massive size and dispersion of military forces. State militaries in the south, like in Mississippi, also rapidly grew in response to the war, requiring a quartermaster system beyond what existed within the militia systems before the war. The state quartermasters struggled to acquire and distribute sufficient supplies to state military forces, in large part due to competition with the Confederate military for resources and personnel. Despite these challenges, quartermaster personnel during the Civil War were usually able to provide sufficient food and uniforms to keep troops effective in the field. (Wikipedia)

Operating at the state level, the Secret Service’s Jackson, Mississippi field office worked with a number of federal agencies on investigations, including the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the U.S. Postal Inspection Service, and the U.S. Capitol Police. (Blain, William T. "Challenge to the Lawless: The Mississippi Secret Service, 1870-1871," Journal of Mississippi History 40, no. 2 (May 1978): 119-31)

Widows were classified as women whose legal husband died and they had not legally remarried (Cambridge Dictionary). Due to the bloodshed of the American Civil War, the United States saw a rapid increase in widowhood in the mid-to-late-nineteenth century; one estimate puts the number of widows at over 200,000 (Essential Civil War Curriculum). The Civil War altered antebellum patterns of widowhood by lowering the average age of widows, since many of those who lost their husbands to the war were in their twenties or thirties, and increasing the number of pregnant widows. Since American coverture legally subsumed a woman's identity under her husbands', many widows had no choice but to quickly remarry for social and economic protection.

The Civil War also altered antebellum grieving traditions in that the presence of so many widows, often many within the same community, became more visible due to their numbers. Antebellum social etiquette also stipulated that a woman grieve her husband for roughly two and a half years, while the experience of war often led widows not only to stop mourning but to start rebuilding their lives (and finding other partners) far quicker. In the South, many women inherited large estates and numerous enslaved people upon their husbands' death, becoming solely responsible for maintaining operations and adopting the role of enslaver.

Widows in both the North and South played outsized roles in commemorating the Civil War and deeply impacted the war's popular memory. Women were societally expected to remember their husbands as honorable, infusing that memory into the statuary and literature of the late-nineteenth and early-twentieth centuries. Antebellum social and legal practices also ensured that women were generally financially dependent upon their husbands, and widowhood thereby faced many women with poverty. Reform agencies therefore often targeted widows in their charitable work, and the widows themselves sought financial assistance from the federal government by applying for pensions, expanding the American welfare state. While widowhood existed prominently throughout the nineteenth century, the Civil War ultimately increased the number of widows and radically altered their places in American life (Essential Civil War Curriculum).

The term "fugitive from justice" is defined broadly and covers a multiplicity of experiences under U.S. law, but refers most often to "a person who is fleeing from custody, whether it be from jail, a government arrest, government or non-government questioning, vigilante violence, or outraged private individuals" (Wikipedia). Slightly different than the above definition, a fugitive from justice may also be defined as "a person formally charged with a crime or a convicted criminal whose punishment has not yet been determined or fully served who is currently beyond the custody or control" of the party, be it local, national, or international, interested in their arrest (Wikipedia). In the nineteenth-century United States, fugitive status varied widely based on race. Many white people considered "fugitives from justice" were most often the latter definition, being those charged with or convicted of crimes who then fled across other state lines to try and evade punishment or trial. However, throughout American history up to Emancipation, fugitive status was given to escaped enslaved African Americans under the Fugitive Slave Laws of 1793 and later 1850. These laws also required anyone in the nation to apprehend self-emancipated enslaved people and return them to their owners. The term "fugitives from justice" therefore became another legal mechanism by which enslavers sought to control the movements and freedoms of the enslaved, while contributing heavily to the increasing sectionalism that would lead to the American Civil War (Britannica). To learn more about enslaved people who emancipations themselves and were labeled fugitives, see the "Emancipation and self-emancipation" subject tag under Events.

element.value: From the Mississippi Department of Archives and History Governor Alcorn Collection. Report from William Morest at Grenada, Mississippi, to L. M. Hall, chief of the Mississippi Secret Service, stating what part of the state he is working in. He also states that the officials from several counties are cooperating with him in his investigation into the assassination of W. F. Brantley, mayor of Winona, Mississippi, and his tracking of fugitives who have escaped from jail in those counties. He recounts his conversation with Brantley's widow. Morest further explains his intentions to carry out the investigation.

div.p:
Head-Quarters Post of Grenada,
(Office of A. A. Q. M.,)
Grenada, Mississippi, August 27, 1870.

To M. L. M. Hall
Chief of the State Secret Service
For the State of Mississippi
I herewith state my routes so as to show in what Portion of the State I am Engaged in. for the Detection of Crime, and to obtain full and Correct information as partaining to my Sirvice

Lafayette County Pontotoc Co Yellowbush Co Grenada Co Choctow Co Carrol Co and DeSota Panola Co the Cival Officers of the above Counties are in full Concord with me and your Dept,, any information they can give in these respective Counties they willingley and cheerfully do so so as to enable me to Capture fugitives who Escaped from Jail and the laws of the State. I am obtaining a full and correct Discription from the late assassination of Mr Brantley the Mayor of Winona Miss

of the supposed assassin, it was a fearfull Crime enacted on a peacefull Citizen and Official I visited the residence of Mr Brantley late Mayor of Winona his wife and family are indeed entitled to sympathy. I will not attempt to describe the scene it was heart-rendering which has followed the murdered mans Wife and family. Grief Like theirs can not be Portrayed, with sad hearts they Explained all they know to me. I cannot see what gave the assassin any Chance for Escape but aso to Just as I have said it is impossible to Empannel a Jurry to Convict and it is almost impossible to get any one to give any information, the information I want will come slow, but patiance will accomplish all. in regards to Charles E Mooney the assassin of Mr West for which a heavy reward is out I have obtained his Potograph and I believe full and reliable information all I am waiting for is instruction for to go after him his Destination is in Texas I am working up Cases in different parts in different Counties all for the good of the

Secret Service and the State of Mississippi as soon as I obtain a full and Correct Discription and reliable information of the suppossed murderer of Mr Brantley the Mayor late of Winona I shall forward To Hd Quarters. at the same time I will work on other Cases,, and do expect to receive instructions from time to time,, If I had the letter to the President of the Mississippi Central R R and Baltimore and Ohio I could get my half price fare, also I could make arrangements with the Mississippi and Tennessee R R,, had I a letter to either of the president or Superintendents I shall Dispatch for more money ere this reaches you through Mail, every thing goese slow. I shall render an account Ihope satisfactory. Ihope you received my suite of clothing and will take the best of care take them to a secure place till I come to my head Quarters, and I shall ever consider myself under many oblications to his honor the Chief for his everlasting Kindness and for the confidence bestowed on me by His Excelancy the Governor and his honor ^my^ the Chief
I shall endevor to still more try to merit the trust placed in me and therefore will ever be watchfull to serve my Employer faithfully for the good of the Service.
